evidence_span: Acicular Structures—The acicular structure chosen for study was characterized by very coarse prior-beta grains with broad groups of parallel platelets up to several millimetres in length.

evidence_span: Figure 2a shows the surface appearance of three adjacent prior-beta grains with markedly different corrosion behaviors.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: Moreover, it can be seen that the nodules initiated on certain needles remain well localized, with little tendency to rapid lateral growth (Fig. 2d).

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: Finally, it should be noted that oxide growth is retarded above precipitate-rich regions, as shown in Fig. $2 c$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: It is also interesting to point out that, after corrosion, the hydrides are all located near intermetallic precipitates in the vicinity of platelet junctions, that is, in the zones with the highest corrosion resistance.

evidence_span: TEM examinations of thin foils by electrons diffraction have shown that two adjacent grains can have misorientations as low as $2 ^ { \circ }$ .

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens were heat-treated in one of two ways to obtain very large alpha grains with or without precipitates.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: The first technique consisted in heating into the beta field, followed by slow cooling into the alpha $+$ beta region, and then rapidly cooling down to room temperature.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: The second type of treatment involved cooling very slowly down to room temperature from the beta phase, in order to produce large needles, several millimetres in length, followed by reheating into the alpha $^ +$ beta field and quenching.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: The corrosion behavior of these two materials is summarized by the cross sections shown in Fig. 5, corresponding to specimens exposed for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at $5 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: It can clearly be seen that the prior-beta grains, which contain practically all of the iron and chromium, have very good corrosion resistance, whereas the precipitate-free regions are heavily oxidized.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: precipitate-free regions are heavily oxidized.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: the thick scale remains limited to these precipitate-free grains and does not propagate laterally, indicating that the corrosionresistant areas act as barriers, preventing extension of the white oxide.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_026_chunk2
evidence_span: hydride precipitation is essentially limited to the prior-beta regions, that is, those with the highest corrosion resistance.

evidence_span: sheets were produced from a series of experimental ingots, with a constant iron/chromium $\mathrm { ( F e / C r ) }$ ratio of 2, and iron $^ +$ chromium contents from 0.25 to $0 . 4 \%$ .
